The MAC Resolvability Region, Semantic Security and Its Operational Implications

Matthias Frey, Igor BjelakoviÄ‡ and SÅ‚awomir StaÅ„czak
Technische UniversitÃ¤t Berlin
Abstract

Building upon previous work on the relation between secrecy and channel resolvability, we revisit a secrecy proof for the multiple-access channel (MAC) from the perspective of resolvability. In particular, we refine and extend the proof to obtain novel results on the second-order achievable rates. Then we characterize the resolvability region of the memoryless MAC by establishing a conceptually simple converse proof for resolvability that relies on the uniform continuity of Shannonâ€™s entropy with respect to the variational distance. We discuss the operational meaning of the information theoretic concept of semantic security from the viewpoint of Ahlswedeâ€™s General Theory of Information Transfer and show interesting implications on the resilience against a large class of attacks even if no assumption can be made about the distributions of the transmitted messages. Finally we provide details on how the resolvability results can be used to construct a wiretap code that achieves semantic security.

â€ â€ footnotetext: The work was supported by the German Research Foundation (DFG) under grant STA864/7-1 and by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research under grant 16KIS0605. This paper was presented in part at the 4th Workshop on Physical-Layer Methods for Wireless Security held during the 2017 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network SecurityÂ [21].

I Introduction

With an increasing number of users and things being connected to each other, not only the overall amount of communication increases, but also the amount of private and personal information being transferred. This information needs to be protected against various attacks. In fact, for some emerging applications such as e-health services where sensitive medical data might be transmitted using a Body Area Network, the problem of providing secrecy guarantees is a key issue.

As discovered by CsiszÃ¡rÂ [12] and later more explicitly by Bloch and LanemanÂ [10] and investigated by Yassaee and Aref [45] for the multiple-access case, the concept of channel resolvability can be applied to provide such guarantees; in essence, an effective channel is created by an encoder in such a way that the output observed by a wiretapper is almost independent of the transmitted messages, which renders the output useless for the wiretapper. Moreover, the concept can also be used in point-to-point settings as a means of exploiting channel noise to convey randomness in such a way that the distribution observed at the receiver can be accurately controlled by the transmitter.

In this paper, we explore channel resolvability in a multiple-access setting in which there is no communication between the transmitters, yet they can control the distribution observed at the receiver in a non-cooperative manner. More precisely, given a multiple-access channel with an ideal or desired output distribution under some input distribution (see Figure Â 1), the resolvability problem for this multiple-access channel consists in finding for each transmitter a finite sequence of codewords (called a codebook) such that if each transmitter chooses a codeword at random and independently of the other transmitter, then the MAC output well approximates the given ideal output distribution. The coding setting is illustrated in FigureÂ 2 where each codeword is a tuple of nğ‘›n elements of the input alphabet and nğ‘›n is referred to as the block length.

The first part of the paper deals with the resolvability problem for the memoryless MAC, while in the second part we show how the concept of channel resolvability can be exploited to achieve strong operational secrecy guarantees over a wiretap MAC.

I-A Literature

To the best of our knowledge, the concept of approximating a desired output distribution over a communication channel using as little randomness as possible at the transmitter was first introduced by WynerÂ [43], who used normalized Kullback-Leibler divergence as a similarity measure between the actual and the desired output distribution. Han and VerdÃºÂ [25] introduced the term channel resolvability for a similar concept; however, instead of the Kullback-Leibler divergence, they used the variational distance as a metric and showed, among others, the existence of a codebook that achieves an arbitrarily small variational distance by studying the expected variational distance of a random codebook.

A stronger result stating that the probability of drawing an unsuitable random codebook is doubly exponentially small is due to CuffÂ [14]. Related results were proposed before by CsiszÃ¡rÂ [12] and by DevetakÂ [16] for the quantum setting, who based his work on the non-commutative Chernoff boundÂ [3]. Further secrecy results that are either based on or related to the concept of channel resolvability can be found in HayashiÂ [27], Bloch and Laneman [10], Hou and KramerÂ [29], and Wiese and BocheÂ [42], who applied Devetakâ€™s approach to a multiple-access setting. CuffÂ [14] presented a result on the second-order rate; a related result was proposed by Watanabe and HayashiÂ [41]. Resolvability for MACs has been explored by SteinbergÂ [38] and later by OohamaÂ [36]. Explicit low-complexity codebooks for the special case of symmetric MACs have been proposed by Chou, Bloch and KliewerÂ [11].

Converse results for channel resolvability have been proposed by Han and VerdÃºÂ [25] and, for the multiple-access channel, by SteinbergÂ [38]. However, since these studies consider channels with memory and allow for arbitrary input and output distributions (in particular, they need not be identical or independent across channel uses), these results are not directly transferrable to the memoryless case considered in this paper. Converse proofs for the memoryless single-user case were given by WynerÂ [43] and later by HouÂ [30]; however, instead of the variational distance considered in this study, they assumed the Kullback-Leibler divergence as a similarity measure so that the results of [30] cannot be applied directly either.

Security concepts from cryptography have been redefined as secrecy concepts for the information theoretic setting by Bellare, Tessano and Vardy in [7] and [6], where the authors also discussed the interrelations between these concepts; however, the proposed schemes involve some cryptographic elements, such as shared secrets between transmitter and legitimate receiver or shared (public) randomness. To the best of our knowledge, there are currently no results explicitly linking the concept of semantic security to the operational meaning in communication theory.

Wiretap codes that achieve semantic security over the Gaussian channel have been proposed by Ling, Luzzi, Belfiore and StehlÃ©Â [33]. ThangarajÂ [39] showed how to construct semantically secure wiretap codes for the single-user channel and already noted the link to channel resolvability. Goldfeld, Cuff and PermuterÂ [23][22] showed how channel resolvability techniques can be used to obtain wiretap codebooks that achieve semantic security over the single-user channel; the technique had been previously sketched by CuffÂ [15].

Liang and PoorÂ [32], Ekrem and UlukusÂ [18], as well as Liu and KangÂ [34] provided converse results for related multiple-access wiretap channels, but these results do not carry over in a straightforward fashion to the converse results for the channel model we consider in this paper to study achievable secrecy rates.

II Overview and Main Contributions

The main contributions of this study can be summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We characterize the resolvability region of the discrete memoryless multiple-access channel. Section IV proves the direct theorem and a result on the second-order rate, while Section V deals with the converse theorem.

  2. 2.

    In Section VI we show how resolvability can be exploited to achieve strong secrecy and semantic security, and discuss operational implications of semantic security.

In the remainder of this section, we discuss our results in more detail and explain their implications in the context of secrecy and security. We start with a basic definition and refer the reader to Section III for further definitions.

To prove this theorem, we revisit the proof inÂ [42], thereby focusing on channel resolvability. We use a slightly different technique than that inÂ [14], which we extend to the multiple-access case to provide an explicit statement and a more intuitive proof for a result only implicitly contained inÂ [42]. In an excursus, we show how a slight refinement of the same technique similarly as inÂ [14] yields also a partial second-order result.

In SectionÂ VI, we discuss different notions of secrecy and the interconnection between them. In particular, in addition to the classical concept of strong secrecy, we review the notions of distinguishing security and semantic security, both of which originate from the field of cryptography. Distinguishing security allows us to decompose the problem for wiretap coding into a problem of coding for the MAC and a channel resolvability problem as shown in FigureÂ 4. The concept of semantic security, on the other hand, which is implied by distinguishing security, has some very strong operational implications, some of which we explore from the point of view of Ahlswedeâ€™s General Theory of Information TransferÂ [1].

Theorem 4 (Chernoff-Hoeffding Bound).

This version can e.g. be found inÂ [17, Ex. 1.1]. We also use an extension of the Chernoff-Hoeffding bound for dependent variables due to JansonÂ [31, Theorem 2.1], of which we state only a specialized instance that is used in this paper.

Theorem 5 (JansonÂ [31]).

We also useÂ [13, Lemma 2.7] which provides bounds for the entropy difference of random variables that are close to each other in terms of their variational distance. IV Proof of the Direct Theorem

IV-A Second Order Rates

Although the probability statement in TheoremÂ 2 is quite strong in the sense that it guarantees a doubly exponentially low probability of drawing a bad pair of codebooks, a weak spot of the theorem as stated is that the constants Î³1subscriptğ›¾1\gamma_{1} and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2\gamma_{2} are guaranteed to be positive, but can be arbitrarily small depending on the channel, the input distribution and the codebook rates and that the theorem is only valid for sufficiently large nğ‘›n. So in particular, if we are given a fixed nğ‘›n (even a very large one), we cannot draw any conclusions for the error probabilities of codebooks of block length nğ‘›n. However, a closer examination of the proof shows that stronger statements are possible in this case. In this subsection, we give details how the proof of TheoremÂ 2 can be modified so that it yields the following second-order result.

VI Channel Resolvability and Secrecy

In this section, we summarize some existing notions of secrecy and a few facts about their relations to each other, and also discuss their operational meaning. We then show explicitly how our channel resolvability results can be applied to derive a secrecy result for the multiple-access wiretap channel that not only implies strong secrecy, but has even stronger operational properties than the classical notion of strong secrecy. We start by providing additional definitions in SubsectionÂ VI-A, then we discuss different notions of secrecy and interconnections between them in SubsectionÂ VI-B. Then we show how our resolvability results can be used to achieve secrecy over the multiple-access channel. To this end, we first repeat a well-known result on achievable rates for the multiple-access channel in SubsectionÂ VI-C which is the second crucial ingredient besides resolvability for the secrecy theorem we prove in SubsectionÂ VI-D.

VI-A Additional Definitions

In contrast to the other sections, in this section we will also look at probability distributions on the alphabet of possible messages. We therefore use â„³1:={1,â€¦,expâ¡(nâ€‹R1)}assignsubscriptâ„³11â€¦ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…1\mathcal{M}_{1}:=\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{1})\} and â„³2:={1,â€¦,expâ¡(nâ€‹R2)}assignsubscriptâ„³21â€¦ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…2\mathcal{M}_{2}:=\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{2})\} to denote the message alphabets; for convenience we denote by â„³:=â„³1Ã—â„³2assignâ„³subscriptâ„³1subscriptâ„³2\mathcal{M}:=\mathcal{M}_{1}\times\mathcal{M}_{2} the message alphabet of both transmitters. M1subscriptğ‘€1M_{1}, M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{2} and M=(M1,M2)ğ‘€subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2M=(M_{1},M_{2}) are random variables on â„³1subscriptâ„³1\mathcal{M}_{1}, â„³2subscriptâ„³2\mathcal{M}_{2} and â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, respectively, to denote the messages chosen by the transmitters to be sent and pMsubscriptğ‘ğ‘€p_{M} denotes a probability mass function on â„³â„³\mathcal{M} describing the distribution of Mğ‘€M.

By a wiretap channel ğ’²=(ğ’²legit,ğ’²tap)ğ’²subscriptğ’²legitsubscriptğ’²tap\mathcal{W}=({\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{legit}}},{\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{tap}}}), we mean a pair of channels, where ğ’²legit=(ğ’³,ğ’´,ğ’µlegit,qZlegit|X,Y)subscriptğ’²legitğ’³ğ’´subscriptğ’µlegitsubscriptğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘legitğ‘‹ğ‘Œ{\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{legit}}}=(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y},\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{legit}},q_{Z_{\mathrm{legit}}|X,Y}), which we call the legitimate receiverâ€™s channel and ğ’²tap=(ğ’³,ğ’´,ğ’µtap,qZtap|X,Y)subscriptğ’²tapğ’³ğ’´subscriptğ’µtapsubscriptğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘‹ğ‘Œ{\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{tap}}}=(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y},\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}},q_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}|X,Y}), which we call the wiretapperâ€™s channel, share the same input alphabets.

VI-B Secrecy Concepts and their Operational Meanings

In this subsection, we give a short overview over some notions of information-theoretic secrecy. We adapt the notation in the sources we are citing in such a way that it conforms with the notation we have been using in this paper, which is specific to the multiple-access wiretap channel, but the concepts apply also to (and have originally been introduced for) wiretap channels with only one transmitter.

Before we give formal definitions of secrecy, we first take a look at what operational implications we want a good notion of secrecy to have. InÂ [1], Ahlswede generalized the communication task in the following way: The transmitter picks a message Mâˆˆâ„³ğ‘€â„³M\in\mathcal{M}, encodes it and transmits the codeword over a channel. The receiver then aims not necessarily at decoding the exact message Mğ‘€M, but rather has a partition {â„³1,â€¦,â„³â„“}subscriptâ„³1â€¦subscriptâ„³â„“\{\mathcal{M}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{M}_{\ell}\} of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, i.e. disjoint subsets of â„³â„³\mathcal{M} with âˆªk=1â„“â„³k=â„³superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1â„“subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜â„³\cup_{k=1}^{\ell}\mathcal{M}_{k}=\mathcal{M}. Its task is then to reconstruct kğ‘˜k such that Mâˆˆâ„³kğ‘€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜M\in\mathcal{M}_{k}. The transmitter does not know the exact partition Î Î {\Pi} that defines the receiverâ€™s task, but has only a subset {Î 1,â€¦,Î t}subscriptÎ 1â€¦subscriptÎ ğ‘¡\{{\Pi}_{1},\dots,{\Pi}_{t}\} of the set of all possible partitions of â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and has to encode the message in such a way that the receiver can decode with high probability no matter which partition in this set defines its task, or put differently, we assume there is one receiver for each partition and we want each receiver to be able to decode with high probability. Ahlswede gave a list of specializations of this very general concept that he deemed potentially useful for real-world communication systems. Two of these are:

  1. 1.

    t=1ğ‘¡1t=1 and the only partition Î 1subscriptÎ 1{\Pi}_{1} is the partition of singletons {{m}:mâˆˆâ„³}conditional-setğ‘šğ‘šâ„³\{\{m\}:m\in\mathcal{M}\}. Here the receiverâ€™s task amounts to Shannonâ€™s classical decoding problem.

  2. 2.

    t=|â„³|ğ‘¡â„³t=\lvert\mathcal{M}\rvert and the set of partitions is

    {{{m},â„³âˆ–{m}}:mâˆˆâ„³}.conditional-setğ‘šâ„³ğ‘šğ‘šâ„³\Big{\{}\big{\{}\{m\},\mathcal{M}\setminus\{m\}\big{\}}:m\in\mathcal{M}\Big{\}}.

    This corresponds to the problem of identification codes introduced by Ahlswede and DueckÂ [2].

These decoding tasks can not only be understood as having to be performed by a legitimate receiver in cooperation with the transmitter, but can also be seen as possible attacks carried out by a wiretapper, where each possible attack is defined by a partition on â„³â„³\mathcal{M}. For instance, we could deem the wiretapperâ€™s attack to have been successful only if it is able to decode the exact message which corresponds to item 1), or, by an alternative definition, we might choose a particular message mğ‘šm that the wiretapper has to identify corresponding to one of the partitions of item 2) and thus obtain a much weaker definition of what constitutes a successful attack.

The best thing we might wish for in this context would be that the wiretapper be unable to perform attacks corresponding to any possible partition of the message set. In fact, demanding this is equivalent to insisting that the wiretapper shall not be able to decode any function of the transmitted message (because a function induces a partition of its domain via the preimages of singletons in its range).

Shannon introduced the concept of information theoretic secrecy and required for his condition of perfect secrecyÂ [37] that Iâ€‹(M;Ztapn)=0ğ¼ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›0I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n})=0. In Shannonâ€™s cipher system, both legitimate receiver and wiretapper get the same channel output, but transmitter and legitimate receiver share a key, which is unknown to the wiretapper.

Later, Wyner introduced the wiretap channel, where the wiretapperâ€™s channel output is degraded with respect to the legitimate receiverâ€™s channel output, but wiretapper and legitimate receiver do not share a key. In order to be more amenable to analysis, he weakened Shannonâ€™s perfect secrecy criterion and introduced the concept of weak secrecyÂ [44]. A sequence of codes for increasing block length nğ‘›n is said to achieve weak secrecy if Iâ€‹(M;Ztapn)/nğ¼ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›ğ‘›I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n})/n approaches 00 as nğ‘›n tends to infinity, where Mğ‘€M is assumed to be uniformly distributed over the message set. It turns out that a sequence of codes can achieve weak secrecy while the total amount of information leaked still tends to infinity with the block length approaching infinity. Therefore, the notion ofÂ strong secrecy was introduced by MaurerÂ [35] which demands that Iâ€‹(M;Ztapn)ğ¼ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}) shall approach 00 as nğ‘›n tends to infinity, where Mğ‘€M is still assumed to be distributed uniformly.

Strong secrecy has been shown to imply that full decoding is only possible with an error probability that approaches the probability of guessing correctly without any channel output at all and it has also been shown to provide some resilience against identification attacksÂ [9], however, some messages might remain identifiable and no method was proposed of ensuring that any particular given message mğ‘šm not be identifiable.

This leads us to the concept of semantic security, which originates from the field of cryptographyÂ [24], but has also been redefined to yield an information-theoretic secrecy criterionÂ [7][6].

Following the discussion inÂ [6] and adapting to our notation, we say that a sequence of codebooks achieves semantic security if

maxÎ ,â„™M(maxf:ğ’µtapnâ†’Î â„™M,Ztapn(Mâˆˆf(Ztapn))âˆ’maxgâˆˆÎ â„™M(Mâˆˆg))subscriptÎ subscriptâ„™ğ‘€subscript:ğ‘“â†’superscriptsubscriptğ’µtapğ‘›Î subscriptâ„™ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›ğ‘€ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›subscriptğ‘”Î subscriptâ„™ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ‘”\max\limits_{{\Pi},\mathbb{P}_{M}}\bigg{(}\max\limits_{{f}:\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}\rightarrow{\Pi}}\mathbb{P}_{M,Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}}(M\in{f}(Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}))\\ -\max\limits_{{g}\in{\Pi}}\mathbb{P}_{M}(M\in{g})\bigg{)} (46)

tends to 00 with nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty, where Î Î {\Pi} ranges over all partitions of â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and â„™Msubscriptâ„™ğ‘€\mathbb{P}_{M} over all possible probability distributions of Mâˆˆâ„³ğ‘€â„³M\in\mathcal{M}. The positive term can be seen as the probability that the wiretapper solves its decoding task successfully given its channel output and an optimal decoder, while the second term can be seen as subtracting the probability that the decoding task is solved without knowledge of the wiretapperâ€™s channel output (i.e. by optimal guessing). This notion has a wide range of operational implications in the sense that it is impossible for the wiretapper to carry out an attack corresponding to any of Ahlswedeâ€™s general communication tasks, as we show in ExamplesÂ 1 andÂ 2.

Remark 4.

(46) remains unchanged even if we allow stochastic wiretapperâ€™s decoders, i.e. if we let fğ‘“{f} range over functions that map from ğ’µtapnsuperscriptsubscriptğ’µtapğ‘›\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n} to probability mass functions on Î Î {\Pi}.

On the other hand, it is not easy to prove directly that a particular wiretap code achieves semantic security. We therefore define a notion of secrecy that is more amenable to analysis, namely, we say that a sequence of wiretap codebooks achieves distinguishing security if

maxm1,m2,m~1,m~2âˆ¥pZtapn|ğ’1â€‹(m1,â‹…),ğ’2â€‹(m2,â‹…)âˆ’pZtapn|ğ’1â€‹(m~1,â‹…),ğ’2â€‹(m~2,â‹…)âˆ¥TV\max\limits_{m_{1},m_{2},\tilde{m}_{1},\tilde{m}_{2}}\lVert p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(m_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(m_{2},\cdot)}\\ -p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(\tilde{m}_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(\tilde{m}_{2},\cdot)}\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}} (47)

approaches 00 with nğ‘›n tending to infinity.

Remark 5.

Due to the triangle inequality, this notion of distinguishing security is equivalent to

maxm1,m2âˆ¥pZtapn|ğ’1â€‹(m1,â‹…),ğ’2â€‹(m2,â‹…)âˆ’pâˆ¥TV\displaystyle\max\limits_{m_{1},m_{2}}\lVert p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(m_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(m_{2},\cdot)}-p\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}}

approaching 00, where pğ‘p is an arbitrary probability mass function on ğ’µtapnsuperscriptsubscriptğ’µtapğ‘›\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n} that does not change with m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} or m2subscriptğ‘š2m_{2}.

In [6], these and several other related concepts of information-theoretical secrecy and their interrelations are discussed. It turns out that distinguishing and semantic security are equivalent and strictly stronger than strong secrecy. On the other hand, if the definition of strong secrecy is strengthened to demand that maxpMâ¡Iâ€‹(M;Ztapn)subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘€ğ¼ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘tapğ‘›\max_{p_{M}}I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}) approaches 00, where pMsubscriptğ‘ğ‘€p_{M} ranges over all distributions of Mğ‘€M (not just uniform), then it becomes equivalent to the notions of distinguishing and semantic security. We will present here versions of the proofs adapted to our notation only for the implications that seem most important to us in this context, namely that distinguishing security, which we show in TheoremÂ 10 can be achieved over the multiple-access channel, implies both strong secrecy (LemmaÂ 6) and semantic security (LemmaÂ 7).

We now give two examples to show how the concept of semantic security implies resilience to the Ahlswede attacks discussed before. ExampleÂ 1 is a special case of ExampleÂ 2, but we lay it out explicitly anyway because we believe that it illustrates the ideas involved in a particularly accessible way and that the type of attack it describes could be particularly relevant in practice.

VI-C Coding for the Multiple-Access Channel

The capacity region of the multiple-access channel is well known and proofs can be found in almost any textbook on information theory, however, usually only the existence of a suitable codebook is proven. We need here the slightly stronger statement that the probability of randomly choosing a bad codebook is exponentially small, which requires only a slight modification of these proofs, which is, however, normally not given in the textbooks explicitly. For the sake of completeness, we state here the result that we need and present a proof that is similar to the one given inÂ [26].
